The post Just a few days until Jason Derulo and Steven Bartlett join FOMO 2025 at Sala Palatului appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
FOMO, the Festival of Modern Owners, spans five days of conferences, workshops, live interviews, and over 30 networking events and community activations across Bucharest, between May 21-25, 2025. Tickets can be bought here.

Present at the pre-event press conference, His Excellency Giles Portman, the United Kingdom’s Ambassador to Romania said that ”FOMO aligns perfectly with the UK’s development agenda. We’ve surpassed £10 billion in UK-Romania trade. SMEs are engines of prosperity and need real support.”

BCR, the event’s main partner, was represented by Dana Dima, Vice President of Retail & Private Banking, who added that ”FOMO is an open stage for Romanian entrepreneurs who want to believe in themselves. I believe in entrepreneurs who started from scratch and succeeded through consistency and courage.”

“Entrepreneurship is not necessarily about money or financial independence, because honestly, I’ve never worked so hard for so little money! It’s 1% idea and 99% sweat. But when you believe in your project with all your heart, there’s no way you won’t succeed,” confessed Adina Foldager, founder of Adinish, and FOMO speaker.

FOMO brings together over 60 Romanian entrepreneurs, alongside international guests such as Steven Bartlett, Simon Squibb, Dan Priestley, Sara Al Madani, and Jason Derulo, at Sala Palatului and other partner venues: Apollo 111, Nook, Grădina Alhambra, and Sala Luceafărul.

item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis

The travel for a 10 km distance in Bucharest takes up to 31 min 9 s (+20 seconds compared to the 2023 […]

The post Bucharest traffic is getting worse! Romania’s capital ranks 5th at congestion level in the world appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Bucharest is the fifth most congested city in the world, and fourth place in Europe, based on Tom Tom Traffic Index 2025 edition. Romania’s capital sits on 22nd place when it comes to travel time.

The travel for a 10 km distance in Bucharest takes up to 31 min 9 s (+20 seconds compared to the 2023 Traffic Index). A driver in the Romanian capital faces a congestion level of 48% (2 percent more than in 2023).

The worst day to drive through Bucharest in 2024 was Tuesday, November 12, with an average travel time for a 10 km drive of 42 min 53 seconds. Bucharest drivers lost 6 days, 6 hours in their life in traffic due to congestion (5 h 22 min more than in 2023)

London (United Kingdom) remains the most congested city in Europe with an average travel time per 10 km of 33 min 17 s. Dublin (Ireland) is in second place (32 min 45 s for 10 km), followed by Barcelona (Spain) – 31 min 13 s for 10 km.

Featuring 501 cities across 62 countries on 6 continents, the TomTom Traffic Index evaluates cities around the world by their average travel time and congestion level. Top 3 most congested city in the world are Barranquilla (Colombia), Kolkata and Bengaluru (India).

item.title: Wendy’s opens first restaurant in Bucharest with a local twist
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Wendy’s, one of the world’s most iconic fast-food chains, has officially opened its first location in Bucharest at Mega Mall, marking the brand’s second entry into the Romanian market following last week’s debut at the new Moldova Mall in Iași. To celebrate the launch, Wendy’s unveiled a unique take on its classic logo, featuring a […]

The post Wendy’s opens first restaurant in Bucharest with a local twist appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Wendy’s, one of the world’s most iconic fast-food chains, has officially opened its first location in Bucharest at Mega Mall, marking the brand’s second entry into the Romanian market following last week’s debut at the new Moldova Mall in Iași.

To celebrate the launch, Wendy’s unveiled a unique take on its classic logo, featuring a traditional Romanian touch: the iconic red-haired mascot now wears a hand-crafted „ie”, inspired by local motifs. This limited-edition design extends to the restaurant’s packaging, which is produced entirely in Romania.

The Bucharest location offers a menu tailored to local tastes, including Wendy’s signature square beef burgers, chicken sandwiches, chicken nuggets, the beloved Baconator, and the classic Frosty dessert.

Emphasizing freshness and local sourcing, all burgers are made with Romanian beef, while other ingredients such as whole chicken breast, potatoes, tomatoes, lettuce, and milk for the desserts are also locally sourced and prepared on-site.

John and Kathryn Chayka of JKC Capital, the franchise holders for Wendy’s in Romania, have ambitious plans for the brand’s future in the country. With an investment of at least USD 200 million, they aim to open 100 Wendy’s locations nationwide, creating over 5,000 jobs across Romania.

The post Wendy’s opens first restaurant in Bucharest with a local twist appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.

The post New modern tram lines on Exhibition Boulevard in Northern Bucharest appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
The modernization of the tram line along the Exhibition Boulevard, Aviator Popișteanu Street, Puțul lui Crăciun Street, Dornei Street, and Clăbucet Street has started. The rehabilitation of the tram line over a 2 km length means modernizing the platforms and the contact network.

This investment is part of a broad process of 50 kilometers of tram lines modernization, which is absolutely necessary for efficient and sustainable public transport. Work is also underway to modernize tram line 5 connecting Baneasa Airport to the city.

In August 2024, works started on an 18-km section of double tram tracks on Bd. Th. Pallady, Bd. 1 Decembrie 1918, Bd. Basarabia, Calea Călărașilor, Bd. Corneliu Coposu, used by lines 40, 27, 19, 36, and 23.

Bucharest City Hall has bought 100 trams, 100 electric buses, 100 trolleybuses with European money. They all run on the city’s surface transportation network. The price for a 90-minute trip on any STB line is just 3 lei (0.60 EUR).

item.title: Luxury brand ZEGNA opens a store in Bucharest, near the Atheneum
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Global luxury menswear brand ZEGNA opens its first Negozio in Bucharest. The term is used by ZEGNA for its own stores, coming from the Italian language and means ”shop, business, store”. Spanning two floors, the store at 11-13 George Enescu Street, near Calea Victoriei, the city’s main commercial street, retains the building’s distinctive original architectural […]

The post Luxury brand ZEGNA opens a store in Bucharest, near the Atheneum appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Global luxury menswear brand ZEGNA opens its first Negozio in Bucharest. The term is used by ZEGNA for its own stores, coming from the Italian language and means ”shop, business, store”.

Spanning two floors, the store at 11-13 George Enescu Street, near Calea Victoriei, the city’s main commercial street, retains the building’s distinctive original architectural features, authentic parquet flooring, and a grand staircase highlighted by a glass display window, making it a focal point of the location.

On the first floor, it includes a bar inspired by the ZEGNA Caffè atmosphere and is complemented by iconic pieces of furniture such as elegant Minotti chairs and Italian-made Riva 1920 tables. The store showcases the latest men’s collections and iconic pieces such as the Il Conte jacket, the versatile Overshirt, timeless formalwear, and the iconic Triple Stitch shoes.

The new ZEGNA Negozio reflects a stylistic vision that foregrounds the principles of contemporary design, an authentic expression of the brand’s redefined identity under the artistic direction of Alessandro Sartori. The brand’s expertise, history, and tradition of craftsmanship are also embodied in the philosophy of the collections.

item.title: What is the price of a house in Țegheș village, west Bucharest?
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Today, the village is inhabited by more than 11,000 people, 50% of which are employed

The post What is the price of a house in Țegheș village, west Bucharest? appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Over the past 15 years, the residential market in Țegheș village, 24 kilometers from Bucharest city center, has experienced steady growth, with the number of completed homes doubling from 3,274 in 2010 to 6,251 in 2023. According to the National Institute of Statistics, the usable area for which building permits were issued for residential units in 2023 reached 48,500 square meters, double the figure from 2010.

This sustained growth is driven by demand for larger homes in a quieter, greener environment. Today, Țegheș, part of the Domnești commune, is home to over 11,000 residents, 50% of whom are active individuals between the ages of 20 and 49, while 25% are children.

A key factor in this development is affordability: modern homes with private gardens range from EUR 120,000 to EUR 170,000, significantly lower than similar areas in Bucharest. For example, a four-room apartment in Cartierul Latin, approximately 120 square meters, costs EUR 110,000 + VAT, compared to EUR 152,000 + VAT in Drumul Taberei and EUR 196,450 + VAT in Ghencea.

As an example, Forest Vista project is located three minutes from the A0 highway junction and one minute from the new kindergarten in Țegheș. The kindergarten has a capacity of eight preschool groups and occupies an area of 1,000 square meters, following an investment of approximately 6.2 million lei.

Inspired by Scandinavian architecture, Forest Vista villas feature open designs, large glass surfaces, and premium finishes. Prices start at EUR 120,000 + VAT, and clients benefit from customized interior design by professionals.

The post What is the price of a house in Țegheș village, west Bucharest? appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.

item.content:encoded:
Hagag Development Europe is set to open Stirbei Palace, one of the most emblematic historical monuments on Calea Victoriei, in the second half of this year, transforming it in Bucharest into the epicentre of high-end retail in Romania.

Stirbei Palace will host Romania’s first ”luxury department store”, with Dior, Saint Laurent, Valentino Garavani, Celine, Loewe, Zegna, Roger Vivier, Amina Muaddi, Rene Caovilla, Jimmy Choo, Dolce & Gabbana, Moncler, Santoni to cover dedicated area rooms.

The beauty and niche perfumery selection includes rare creations and iconic essences by Chanel, Dior, Hermes, Guerlain, Roja Dove, Maison Francis Kurkdjian, Tom Ford, Kilian, Xerjoff, Amouage, Frederic Malle, Memo, Aqua di Parma and many more. The space will be complemented by a fine dining restaurant and an in-store Champagne Bar.

item.title: Majority of Bucharest residents are concerned about earthquakes
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Fear of earthquakes is more spread among women (62%) compared to men (51%) and the highest levels of concern are found among residents aged 35 to 64

The post Majority of Bucharest residents are concerned about earthquakes appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Over 82% of residents believe that Bucharest is not ready for a major earthquake. In addition, nearly half of respondents (45%) have not taken protective measures yet, although they admit they should, and only 15% developed an action plan in case of an earthquake, according to Bucharest Community Foundation.

Forty-eight years after the devastating 1977 earthquake, fear of earthquakes remains high. 59% of Bucharest residents consider earthquakes a major threat, ranking them as the second biggest reason for concern, after personal health issues (70%), and 57% feel vulnerable in case of a major earthquake.

Fear of earthquakes is more spread among women (62%) compared to men (51%) and the highest levels of concern are found among residents aged 35 to 64. Young generations aged 18 to 24 are more optimistic, with 39% of respondents stating that the city’s preparedness is ”so and so”.

In the event of a major earthquake, Bucharest residents’ main concerns revolve around losing loved ones (83%), building collapses (75%), the risk of injury or death (67%), and losing their home (59%). Some fears are significantly more present among women, such as economic and social instability (37% vs. 24% among men) or loss of personal belongings (32% vs. 22%).

Although 49% of Bucharest residents feel informed about what to do in the event of an earthquake, 43% have not taken any precautionary or informational measures yet. At the same time, approximately 33% have never discussed emergency measures with their family, and 31% say they would only instinctively know what to do during an earthquake.

The post Majority of Bucharest residents are concerned about earthquakes appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.

item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis

The restaurant operates on a 50 square meters surface and 20 new jobs have been created. Earlier this year, in May, Hesburger announced its entry on the Romanian market with the opening of a first restaurant in […]

The post Finnish fast-food chain Hesburger opens its fourth restaurant in Romania appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Hesburger, the largest fast-food restaurant chain in Finland, opens a new restaurant in AFI Cotroceni, following a 500,000 euro investment. The restaurant operates on a 50 square meters surface and 20 new jobs have been created.

Earlier this year, in May, Hesburger announced its entry on the Romanian market with the opening of a first restaurant in Ramnicu Valcea. Since then, the Finnish fast-food chan opened other two locations.

The Finnish company’s expansion plans include opening 10 locations in several cities in Romania, with a total investment reaching EUR 8 million within one year.

Hesburger, founded by Heikki Salmela and his wife Kirsti Salmela, started its fast-food business in 1966 in the small town of Naantali. It currently operates in 9 countries and has over 480 restaurants.

Hesburger has 274 locations in Finland, 61 in Lithuania, 53 in Estonia, 51 in Latvia, 32 in Bulgaria, 7 in Ukraine, 2 in Germany and one in Poland. Their total number of employees exceeds 8,700.

item.title: 7 out of 10 Bucharest residents want a greener city with less construction chaos
item.dc:creator: Cristian Hatis
item.description:
Improving mobility and transportation infrastructure is a priority for 60% of respondents, especially for those up to 42 years of age and those with high incomes

The post 7 out of 10 Bucharest residents want a greener city with less construction chaos appeared first on Bucharest Daily News.
item.content:encoded:
Residents of Bucharest want a greener city, a more balanced urban development with less chaotic constructions and a focus on restoring and preserving historic buildings, an MKOR survey shows.

Thus, 7 out of 10 Bucharest residents believe that the main priority for the future of their city is to create a greener and more sustainable urban environment. They want to reduce pollution and expand green spaces.

Women in Bucharest are concerned about the quality of life in the city, with greater emphasis on sustainable development and environmental protection. They want a cleaner city with more green spaces and well-organized public transport.

Mobility and transport infrastructure, a priority

For city inhabitants, improving mobility and transport infrastructure is essential. 60% of respondents want a city with a well-adapted infrastructure for bicycles and other eco-friendly means of transport.

The development of efficient multimodal transport and the construction of suspended roads are seen as solutions to decongest traffic and reduce pollution. Bucharest residents also want more balanced urban development, less chaotic construction, and a stronger focus on restoring historic buildings.

Economic development and the cost of living are significant to young people, who want a city that offers professional opportunities and affordable living. At the same time, Gen Xers aged 43-58 have a low level of interest in issues such as the economy, employment, and sustainable development.
